div.l: Illam, quidquid agit, quoquo vestigia movit

Tibullus. Tibullus, Elegy 3.8 ("Sulpicia est tibi culta tuis, / Mars magne, kalendis"), lines 7-8: "Whatsoever [Love] does, whithersoever she turns her steps, / Grace follows her unseen to order all aright" (J. P. Postgate translation).

lg.l: From the soothed breast each trouble flies
And care is charmed the while.
And her soft voice in that calm hour
Even thus, a mild and placid light
Dispels around the gloom of night
But when by every grace arrayed
In the light dance the peerless maid
The kindling eye with eager gaze
It is not now the lambent flame
Those charms a brighter image claim
The blazing torch when waved on high,
That strikes at once the daring eye
Soothed or enraptured thus we seem
As the same calm or brandished beam
